(Theorem 14.3, auxiliary) Recession directions of the Fenchel biconjugate lie in the closure of the recession directions of Unknown identifier `k`k.

This is the missing structural bridge in the conic-separation proof of Theorem 14.3.

(Theorem 14.3, auxiliary) Geometric conversion step for the separation proof.

This is the missing implication in the contradiction argument: if a point is nonpositive under every functional in the closed cone generated by { | sorry * 0} : Set { | Unknown identifier `f`f* 0}, then Unknown identifier `x`x lies in the closed cone generated by {x | sorry 0} : Set ?m.1{x | Unknown identifier `f`f x 0}.

The textbook proof routes this through the positively-homogeneous hull Unknown identifier `k`k of Unknown identifier `f`f, the conjugacy , and the polar/recession correspondence (Theorem 14.2).
